Context:
Program Name: Theatre Arts – Performance
Code: P104
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $5,451.00 *
International Tuition: $19,280.00 **
Program Location: Young Centre for the Performing Arts in Toronto’s Distillery District
Program Overview: Intensive training program to become a professional actor with industry professionals as instructors.
Disclaimer: Includes expectations of professionalism, group work, intimacy between actors, whispering, consensual touching, combat training, expressions of physicality, deep exploration of self, personal psychological examination, conflict, and successful failure.

* Domestic tuition fee for 1 year
** International tuition fee for 1 year

Context:
The text is about a Theatre Arts – Performance program offered by George Brown College. The curriculum includes five core skill courses: voice, speech, movement, music, and dance. Students will also take classes in improvisation, storytelling, poetry, clowning, stage combat, commedia dell’arte, and more. They will learn how to prepare for auditions and have opportunities to immerse themselves in Toronto's theatre scene through partnerships with Soulpepper Theatre Company, Tarragon Theatre, and Theatre by the Bay. In their final year, students are paired with a seasoned theatre practitioner as a mentor.

Graduates of this program are eligible to become members of ACTRA and UDA sooner than graduates from non-accredited schools. For ACTRA, new graduates can apply within one year and join as an Apprentice member. For UDA, graduates can acquire 15 of the 30 credits required to become an active member under certain conditions.

Required courses for Semester 1 include Acting I (THEA 1001), Dance I (THEA 1003), Movement I (THEA 1004), Vocal Music I (THEA 1005). There is no information about pre-requisites or the number of credits for each course in the text.

George Brown College is recognized by ACTRA and UDA as an accredited training institution. The text also mentions opportunities for future study, but there is no link provided to the Transfer Guide.

There is no information about years, numbers, emails, or names in the text.

Context:
THEA 3019 (auditioning I), THEA 2025 (Business of Acting II), THEA 3021 (Film Acting II), THEA 3010 (Showcase Performance II), THEA 3013 (Movement VI), THEA 3021 (Playwriting II), THEA 3015 (Introduction to Alexander Technique II), THEA 3020 (Auditioning II) are the courses offered in semester 6 with successful completion of all semester five courses as a prerequisite.

Program Learning Outcomes: The graduate will be able to perform in a variety of theatrical contexts by applying acting, movement and voice techniques as required; develop and present strategies for personal, career and professional development within the performing arts industry; apply and analyze theatre traditions and current trends from a variety of historical and cultural contexts to enhance personal creativity and theatrical performance; investigate and articulate personal reasons for pursuing creative work in the theatre; complete all work in compliance with industry standards and policies and professional ethics; use entrepreneurial and project-planning skills to develop production and administrative aspects of professional theatre; perform vocal material – solo and choral – and execute staging and choreography as required by a theatrical performance; create and devise original works of theatre individually and collectively to perform in front of an audience.

Tuition & Fees: Domestic Tuition: $5,451.00, International Tuition: $19,280.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023. Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates. No specific courses or names mentioned in the text regarding General Education Electives or Program Learning Outcomes.

Context:
* The fees listed are for programs starting in Fall 2024.
* Tuition fees are subject to board approval.
* Material, student service and ancillary fees are estimated based on prior years.
* There is a $50 audition fee for P101, P102, P103, and P104 programs.
* International students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
* The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria.
* Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and pass an interview and audition.
* Enrolment is limited and admission is competitive, based on the results of auditions and personal interviews.
* Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade to achieve the needed credits in English.
* Course credits from colleges or universities may qualify for course exemptions.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Theatre Arts – Performance Program P104 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
* The college offers course exemptions based on previously earned college or university credits. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide.
* International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Applicants for the Theatre Arts – Performance program are required to present two contrasting monologues and one song during auditions. Each monologue must not exceed one and a half minutes, and they must be from published plays. Applicants should also prepare one song to sing without accompaniment.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System.
* Contact information for the School of Media and Performing Arts: phone number 416-415-5000, ext. 2167 and email performingarts@georgebrown.ca.
* Additional contact options are available on the International Contact Us page or by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through that page as well.
* The Theatre Arts – Performance program is located at the Young Centre for Performing Arts in Toronto's Distillery District. Campus tours and a virtual tour are offered.
* Related programs include Acting for Media (P107), Graphic Design (G102), and Video Design & Production (P112).
* The classical theatre training program at George Brown College is renowned in the country.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Theatre Arts – Performance Program P104 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: George Brown Theatre School offers the best classical theatre training program in Canada with highly committed guest artists, faculty, and facilities. The program is demanding and focuses on providing current and practical training in text-based theatre from George Bernard Shaw to Judith Thompson. For more information about the Ontario College Advanced Diploma offered by George Brown Theatre School, visit their campus or sign up for tailored resources and email communications.
